hedline.hl2: The Sauna Essentials: Stoves and Rocks

abstract.p: Article by Bryant Urstadt, who describes building Finnish sauna in rural Vermont; photo (M)

block.p: IT'S best to buy a wood stove and other sauna paraphernalia near home. Stoves are heavy, and if you order from Finland you will pay as much for shipping as heating.

Nippa Sauna Stoves in Bruce Crossing, Mich., has American-made stoves that start at $575, plus shipping. The smallest weighs 190 pounds. The rocks, weighing at least 75 pounds, are extra; (906) 827-3906 or www.nippa.com.

Closer to New York is the Saunastore in Cherry Hill, N.J., whose basic wood stove is $826 and weighs 132 pounds, not including rocks; (856) 489-1594 or www.saunastore.com.

I salvaged some of the wood for my sauna from an old bar, so I saved myself some expense. Some interior woods, like Western red cedar, are more desirable and also more expensive. For a free-standing family-size sauna, count on at least $5,000 for materials.

For those who prefer to hire an expert, Nils Per Shenholm of Solhem Sauna in Duxbury, Vt., designs and builds saunas for customers in New England. Construction and delivery start at $7,000; www.saunavermont.com or (802) 244-6460.
